results.headline: Director Gleefully Tests the Limits of Free Expression
results.summary_short: In the documentary “The Sheik and I,” the director Caveh Zahedi waves the freedom-of-speech flag in a major Arab emirate.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sheik and I

results.headline: Hairless, Bunny-Eared and Sharp-Tongued Philosopher
results.summary_short: A precocious cat anchors a daisy-chain of interfaith dialogues.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Rabbi's Cat

results.headline: A Long Island Clan With a Big Question
results.summary_short: Edward Burns’s film “The Fitzgerald Family Christmas” looks at the lives of an Irish-American family on Long Island.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Fitzgerald Family Christmas

results.headline: How to Appreciate Wagner While Keeping Hitler at Bay
results.summary_short: A fan of Richard Wagner’s music, but not the man, Stephen Fry follows the compositions and their anti-Semitic baggage in the movie “Wagner & Me.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wagner & Me

results.headline: Too Old to Score Goals, He Still Lives to Score
results.summary_short: In Gabriele Muccino’s “Playing for Keeps” Gerard Butler portrays a former soccer star who spends his time coaching his son’s team and bedding mothers of his young players.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Playing For Keeps

results.headline: Destination: Adulthood, by Way of the Skate Park
results.summary_short: Three skateboarding California teenagers are the subjects of “Only the Young,” an unadorned documentary without voice-overs or hectoring.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Only the Young

results.headline: Dad and Daughter Seek Common Ground
results.summary_short: “Off White Lies” is an unconventional look at the growing connection between a shy teenage girl and her shiftless father.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Off White Lies

results.headline: She Came to Sin City for a Wholesome Life
results.summary_short: Beth Raymer’s memoir of her gambling life is brought to the screen in “Lay the Favorite,” starring Rebecca Hall and Bruce Willis.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lay the Favorite

results.headline: Father-Son Ties, Already Strained, Face a Test
results.summary_short: Anguish and tension unfold in “In Our Nature” when a father and a son, with their girlfriends, have an unintentional reunion at an upstate New York home.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Our Nature

results.headline: Kissing Cousins: One Is President
results.summary_short: Bill Murray portrays Franklin D. Roosevelt in “Hyde Park on Hudson,” which depicts a dalliance with his cousin Daisy Suckley.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hyde Park On Hudson

results.headline: Wounded Vets Battling Institutional Neglect
results.summary_short: In this rehab drama by K. Lorrel Manning, a wounded Marine finds a way to combat his postwar grief in a veterans hospital.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy New Year

results.headline: Wisecracking Jungle Animals on an Ecological Crusade
results.summary_short: Animals whose forest home is being threatened by callous developers decide to hike to New Delhi to try to get their grievances heard.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delhi Safari

results.headline: Red Splashes on Snow Bring Horrors Home
results.summary_short: “Deadfall” evokes noirs, including those with a western twang, despite the story’s frozen landscape.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deadfall

results.headline: There Will Always Be a Fantasy England
results.summary_short: Donald Rice’s film “Cheerful Weather for the Wedding” resembles “Downton Abbey,” complete with Elizabeth McGovern, but also with a difference.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cheerful Weather For The Wedding

results.headline: Fable of Tangy Pleasures and Grim Realities on Guadeloupe
results.summary_short: In “Elza,” a Parisian student returns to her birthplace on Guadeloupe to seek the father she barely remembers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elza

results.headline: Midlife Crisis of the Britpunk Kind
results.summary_short: “California Solo” is a wry study of midlife crisis, with Robert Carlyle as a onetime darling of the Britpunk scene driven by past tragedy to a farm outside Los Angeles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of California Solo

results.headline: The Dead Man Had an Oddly Familiar Name
results.summary_short: “Talaash” brings together the Cool Kids of Bollywood cinema (Aamir Khan, Reema Kagti and Zoya Akhtar) for a stylish thriller.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Talaash

results.headline: Hormone-Addled Teenagers After a Dictatorship
results.summary_short: In “Young and Wild,” adolescents explore sexual liberation in a country not long ago liberated from the Pinochet government.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Young & Wild

results.headline: A Schoolteacher Searching for His Machismo
results.summary_short: In the German film “What a Man,” Matthias Schweighöfer learns to accept himself as he is, even if it’s not what his girlfriend wanted.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What a Man

results.headline: A Road Trip With Mom Goes Awry
results.summary_short: In “Walk Away Renee,” a son makes a documentary about his journey with his schizophrenic mother and her missing medications.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walk Away Renée
